articles.headline: Greenspan Concedes That the Fed Failed to Gauge the Bubble
articles.snippet: In his most detailed examination of the causes of the financial crisis, however, the former Fed chairman says the policy of low interest rates was not to blame.
articles.abstract: In his most detailed examination of the causes of the financial crisis, however, the former Fed chairman says the policy of low interest rates was not to blame.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Is Alan Greenspan, famous for his libertarian leanings and hands-off approach to Wall Street, having some second thoughts?

articles.headline: Viacom Says YouTube Ignored Copyrights
articles.snippet: The charge was one of many made by Viacom in filings in its copyright lawsuit against YouTube and Google.
articles.abstract: The charge was one of many made by Viacom in filings in its copyright lawsuit against YouTube and Google.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Pointing to internal YouTube e-mail messages, Viacom said in a court filing that the video site’s founders turned a blind eye when users uploaded copyrighted clips so they could amass a big audience and sell the company quickly.

articles.headline: Doctor Asserts Church Ignored Abuse Warnings
articles.snippet: A psychiatrist said that the German archdiocese led by the future Pope Benedict XVI ignored his warnings in the early 1980s about a priest accused of sexually abusing boys.
articles.abstract: A psychiatrist said that the German archdiocese led by the future Pope Benedict XVI ignored his warnings in the early 1980s about a priest accused of sexually abusing boys.
articles.lead_paragraph: ESSEN, Germany — The German archdiocese led by the future Pope Benedict XVI ignored repeated warnings in the early 1980s by a psychiatrist treating a priest accused of sexually abusing boys that he should not be allowed to work with children, the psychiatrist said Thursday.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish and Katrin Bennhold

articles.headline: Germany Backtracks on Europe Rescue for Greece
articles.snippet: After originally backing a European rescue for Greece, Germany signaled that help should come from the I.M.F.
articles.abstract: After originally backing a European rescue for Greece, Germany signaled that help should come from the I.M.F.
articles.lead_paragraph: After weeks of backing a European rescue for the financially troubled Greece, Germany shifted course on Thursday, signaling that help should come from the International Monetary Fund rather than Greece’s neighbors.
articles.byline: By Matthew Saltmarsh and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: Safety Issues Linger as Nuclear Reactors Shrink in Size
articles.snippet: Some environmentalists said the nuclear industry would be risking its green record if it adapted smaller nuclear reactors, like those once used in submarines, to light a city.
articles.abstract: Some environmentalists said the nuclear industry would be risking its green record if it adapted smaller nuclear reactors, like those once used in submarines, to light a city.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — When the Soviet Union introduced its Alfa class submarine — at the time, the world’s fastest — the subs were the bane of American sailors. Now, the reactors that powered those submarines are being marketed as the next innovation in green power.

articles.headline: A Company Races to Keep a Drug Patent
articles.snippet: The Medicines Company is disputing whether it really did miss a deadline in applying for a patent extension for its blood thinner Angiomax.
articles.abstract: The Medicines Company is disputing whether it really did miss a deadline in applying for a patent extension for its blood thinner Angiomax.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been called a case of being a day late and a billion dollars short — potentially one of the costliest blunders in drug industry history. But a court decision this week might be a reprieve for the company involved.

articles.headline: After a Bitter Campaign, Forging an Alliance
articles.snippet: President Obama and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton have formed a surprisingly credible partnership.
articles.abstract: President Obama and Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton have formed a surprisingly credible partnership.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On a snowy Thursday shortly before her weekly meeting with President Obama last month, Hillary Rodham Clinton got a distressing phone call: her husband, Bill Clinton, was in a hospital with chest pains and needed an urgent heart procedure.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: For India’s Newly Rich Farmers, Limos Won’t Do
articles.snippet: Land acquisition has created pockets of instant wealth and a new economic caste in India: nouveau riche farmers.
articles.abstract: Land acquisition has created pockets of instant wealth and a new economic caste in India: nouveau riche farmers.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOIDA, India — Bhisham Singh Yadav, father of the groom, is stressed. His rented Lexus got stuck behind a bullock cart. He has hired a truck to blast Hindi pop, but it is too big to maneuver through his village. At least his grandest gesture, evidence of his upward mobility, is circling overhead. The helicopter has arrived.

articles.headline: Stressful but Vital: Picking a Nursing Home
articles.snippet: Finding a good one takes research and perseverance, but unfortunately, the typical search is made under duress and with little time available.
articles.abstract: Finding a good one takes research and perseverance, but unfortunately, the typical search is made under duress and with little time available.
articles.lead_paragraph: The decision is one of the hardest you will ever make. Your spouse, parent or another loved one needs care that assisted living or home health care simply cannot provide. You need to choose a nursing home.
